BC-CIR-HIDDEN-FENCES-NYT 
HIDDEN ELECTRONIC FENCES CAN KEEP DOGS FROM GOING ASTRAY 

   By SHELLY FREIERMAN   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   No amount of scolding, begging or foot-stomping will keep most
dogs home in their yards and out of the streets. So some frazzled
owners try to turn their neighborhood travelers into docile
homebodies with radio-controlled fences.

   These hidden fences consist of wire loops, buried an inch or two
below the surface, that emit radio signals when connected to
transmitters. Each dog wears a collar with a receiver; when the dog
gets too close to the wire, the collar emits a warning beep. If the
dog ignores the beep, the collar's two metal prongs give the dog a
mild shock, or a series of shocks if the dog persists.

   Debby and Ed Christian have two Old English sheepdogs, who are
so well trained by a hidden fence that they never leave the
Christians' yard in Acton, Mass. ``I could probably not even use
the collars anymore,'' Christian said, ``and the dogs would stay.
Even when another dog comes into the yard, my dogs won't leave.''

   The Christians bought a version called Invisible Fence, made by
ISCO Enterprises. Their 8-year-old male, Fletcher, and 2-year-old
female, Phoebe, figured out the invisible barrier right away.

   When dogs are trained, flags are posted along the boundary wire
and the dogs are walked toward them on a leash. As the dogs
approach the flags, the dogs hear their collars beep. They are told
``no'' and are turned back toward the house. The final step in the
process, which is repeated over several days, is to deliver a mild
shock _ or correction, the euphemism favored by all the
hidden-fence manufacturers _ to reinforce the idea that the dog
should not cross the boundary line. Some dogs require only one
shock to learn to stay within the hidden fence, while others need
several.

   The shock hurts the dog, but it causes no lasting harm. The dogs
yelp, said Dr. Melissa Bain, a resident in clinical animal behavior
at the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of
California at Davis, but the punishment has to be unpleasant to be
effective.

   ``I was petrified of what was going to happen when the shock was
given,'' Christian said. ``Fletcher jumped in the air and never
went near the boundary again.''

   ``The shock works,'' said Dr. Katherine Houpt, the director of
the Animal Behavioral Clinic for the College of Veterinary Medicine
at Cornell University, ``because it is simple aversion learning.
However, it works best with those dogs that are not highly
motivated to leave.'' Among the more difficult pupils she described
are male dogs that are not neutered, dogs that like to hunt or
chase cars and highly territorial dogs that are eager to cross
boundaries to scare off approaching strangers.

   The Invisible Fence was invented in 1973 by Richard Peck, a
traveling salesman and animal lover who was saddened by the number
of dead dogs he saw on the side of the road. When his patents
expired in 1990, several other companies joined the industry. Some
of the products, like Invisible Fence and DogWatch, made by
DogWatch Inc., are sold by independent dealers who install the
product and usually train the dogs (and owners).

   While prices vary among dealers nationally, a system enclosing a
quarter-acre costs about $600 from Invisible Fences and about $900
from DogWatch. Even the most expensive hidden fence is considerably
cheaper than a chain-link or wood fence.

   Products that are installed by the customer, who has to bury the
wire around the perimeter of the property and do the dog training,
cost much less. Radio Systems Corp. of Concord, Tenn., for example,
sells a system, under the PetSafe brand, that will enclose 25 acres
for just under $200.

   Some dogs are willing to endure the punishment in order to leave
the property, especially when they learn that the shock is brief.
One such dog is Teddy, a 3-year-old Pomeranian-and-terrier mix
owned by Renee and Gregory Abel of St. Louis.

   ``If she sees a dog walking by the yard, she doesn't care about
the zap,'' Abel said. ``She'll run through it. We have to go get
her, take off the collar and carry her back over the wire.'' The
fence system works about 85 percent of the time, Abel said. ``I
feel bad about the shock, but we'd feel worse if she got lost or
hit by a car.''

   A hidden fence may protect a dog that is prone to roam, but it
does not necessarily protect strangers approaching the yard. The
dog knows where the boundary is, Houpt said, but a visitor like a
letter carrier may not know that there is a fence.

   Bain also says that is a drawback of hidden fences. If a
stranger steps into the yard, she said, the dog can become
aggressive because someone is in its territory. ``The aggression
can range from chasing them to biting them, depending on the dog,''
she said. ``We tell people with aggressive dogs to get a real
fence,'' she added.

   Hidden-fence companies can tailor their fences to the needs and
quirks of individual dogs and owners. Most of the companies offer
collars with different shock levels, and the fences can also be
used to protect flowerbeds or pools. Invisible Fence has a
three-sided wire system for lakefront properties.

   For owners who would rather not shock their dogs, PetSafe has a
collar that emits a spray of citronella instead; most dogs do not
like the smell. PetSafe also offers a wireless product that keeps
the dog in a 90-foot radius around the transmitter.

   Some dogs can outsmart a hidden fence. They have figured out
that if they stand near the boundary wire to trigger the beep, the
battery will eventually run out and they can come and go without a
shock. In December, PetSafe will introduce a collar that is
designed to discourage escapees by progressively increasing the
intensity of the shock as the dog approaches the fence.

   Dogs can sometimes be shocked even when they are on good
behavior because of interference by television signals. DogWatch
has switched from the standard AM radio signal to a more precise FM
signal for its transmitters to avoid that problem.

   Still, no matter what the companies come up with, some dogs
won't stay put _ a squirrel or a cat across the street can become
just too enticing. ``It is always better to have the dog in the
house unless you can walk it on a leash,'' Houpt said. ``Yes, it's
true a dog needs exercise, but probably so does its owners.''
